In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Dialogue between the Government of Viet Nam and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
has highlighted the importance of providing timely policy guidance to the Ministry of Transport 
(MOT) and its line agencies.  An ADB fact-finding mission met with MOT officials in April 2010 to 
prepare the technical assistance (TA) and reached an understanding with the government on its 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference. The concept paper of the TA was approved by the director general of the 
ADB Southeast Asia Department on 26 March 2010. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam faces substantial challenges in providing new and improved infrastructure for 
its  rapidly  growing  economy.  Investment  in  the  transport  and  communications  sector  is 
expanding at a rapid rate and has more than doubled since 2004 as a percentage of gross 
domestic product (GDP). Transport and communications accounted for 4.5% of GDP in 2009. In 
the next decade, 2011–2020, it is expected that infrastructure development will require as much 
as $16 billion annually, or 20% of projected GDP. In the transport sector, investment in the road 
subsector predominates, accounting for 3.6% of GDP. However, inefficiencies in the transport 
sector hamper the impact and outcomes of these investments. 
 
3.  ADB's country strategy and program for Viet Nam, 2007–2010 and its midterm review 
identified inefficient management as a key issue in the transport sector.2 The timing of the TA is 
important because (i) the road subsector of MOT is being reorganized, with the establishment of 
the  Directorate  for  Roads  of  Vietnam  (DRVN)  and  the  Vietnam  Expressway  Management 
Administration3  (VEMA);  (ii)  a  road  maintenance  fund  under  preparation;  (iii) government 
subsidies  for  expressways  under  consideration;  and  (iv)  development  partners  funding  TA 
projects4 that will supplement and add value to this TA.   
 
4.  The  sector  assistance  program  evaluation  for  the  transport  sector  in  Viet  Nam5 
recommended (i) developing a governance plan to address comprehensively the institution-
building and organizational changes required to mitigate the risks of the current institutional 
arrangements; (ii) considering the provision of real-time advisory support to the government for 
new areas of intervention, such as private sector participation in investments; (iii) improving the 
sustainability of projects by gaining government commitment to fund maintenance in close 
cooperation with other development partners; (iv) reviewing bidding arrangements to ensure 
that  underbidding  does  not  adversely  affect  project  performance  and  that  transparency  is 
maintained in contracts with equitized6 state-owned enterprises (SOEs); and (v) enhancing 
design flexibility.7

5.  MOT is undertaking a major reorganization to create full-service regulating entities for 
roads and expressways. The Vietnam Road Administration was merged with several project 
management units and transformed into the DRVN on 15 March 2010. The responsibilities and 
authority of the former Vietnam Road Administration were primarily for road operation and 
maintenance. The newly formed DRVN is more comprehensive, and its responsibilities include 
(i) policy making, planning, investment, and finance; (ii) traffic safety, road management, and 
maintenance; (iii) vehicle registration and licensing; and (iv) project management. However, 
MOT’s  project  management  units  need  further  improvement  in  management  capability  for 
developing, operating, and maintaining road networks. VEMA will be a regulating entity for 
expressways and is expected to be established in 2010. MOT has prepared a proposal on the 
scope of VEMA, with support from the World Bank,8 based on studies in nine countries, 
including the People’s Republic of China, India, Japan, the Republic of Korea, and Malaysia.  
 
6.  The Vietnam Expressway Corporation (VEC) was established as an SOE under MOT in 
October 2004. The immediate objective of VEC was to prepare an expressway master plan and 
develop new expressways based on it. ADB provided TA to help VEC prepare the master plan.9 
Since  then,  VEC  has  engaged  in  several  expressway  projects  financed  by  ADB,  other 
development partners, and the government. The demarcation of responsibilities between VEMA 
and  VEC  needs  to  be  carefully  addressed  when  VEMA  is  established.  The  financial 
sustainability of VEC and the financial viability of its projects will need to be improved as its 
project portfolio expands. Currently, no tolled expressway is fully operational in Viet Nam, and 
social acceptance of, and willingness to pay, expressway tolls are uncertain. ADB supported 
VEC in building a financial information and management system, but it has yet to become fully 
operational.  
 
7.  The Prime Minister issued a decision10 in January 2010 on the detailed master plan for 
the  north–south  expressway  (eastern  side),  dividing  the  1,811-kilometer  expressway  into 
16 sections, approving the alignment and technical standards, and providing details of land that 
has to be appropriated. The decision sets a 14-year schedule for implementation: 2010–2023. 
The expressway is expected to cost $17.9 billion, or about $10 million per kilometer, and will 
require an average yearly investment of $1.3 billion during implementation. The funding is 
expected to come from both the public and the private sector. 
 
8.  Private  sector  participation  in  expressway  projects  is  at  a  nascent  stage.  The 
government needs private sector investment to fill the huge financial gap between infrastructure 
demand and available budget. The World Bank and the United States Agency for International 
Development  are  working  with  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investment  on  institutional 
arrangements to manage the overall public–private partnership (PPP) program in Viet Nam, 
including a regulatory framework for identifying, appraising, and implementing PPP projects. 
The intent is that the draft framework will be tested through pilot PPP projects, but these pilot 
projects have not so far been confirmed. The government seeks a PPP arrangement for the My 
Thuan–Can Tho expressway project, which ADB was requested to finance. The My Thuan 
project management unit is currently responsible for the project. MOT plans to transform this

9.  Many roads across the country are deteriorating because of (i) design standards that are 
inadequate  to  support  traffic  loads  and  (ii)  inadequate  routine  maintenance.  The  National 
Assembly of Viet Nam approved the establishment of road maintenance funds in November 
2008. MOT is working on implementation details of the funds with support from the World Bank. 
However, the road asset management system and its database, which will be the basis for 
assessing  maintenance  needs  and  fund  allocations,  remain  incomplete.  ADB  has  been 
coordinating closely with the Japan International Cooperation Agency, which plans technical 
cooperation to develop a national road infrastructure database in 2010.11 Design standards 
should be applied flexibly in line with topographical constraints and the nature of traffic so that 
life-cycle costs can be minimized. 
 
10.  MOT has more than 200 SOEs, half of which are in construction. According to ADB's 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), SOEs which are not (i) legally 
and financially autonomous, (ii) operate under commercial law, and (iii) dependent agencies of 
borrower or sub-borrower are ineligible to bid under ADB-financed projects to avoid potential 
conflict of interest. This leaves large and experienced SOEs, particularly those under MOT, 
unable to compete for contracts. However, it started to be recognized and further assessed in 
the TA that the mechanism and degree of MOT’s control over SOEs has changed recently as a 
result of SOE reforms like equitization and privatization. ADB's procurement should be carried 
out  in  a  way  that  ensures  all  eligible,  experienced,  and  willing  contractors  are  given  fair 
opportunity, as this will increase competition and promote timely project implementation by 
qualified contractors.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be the transformation of MOT and its line agencies into 
streamlined and efficient organizations. The outcome of the TA will be road maps, guidelines, 
and assessments to be developed by the TA on key issues in the road transport subsector 
being submitted to and reviewed by the appropriate authority within MOT and its line agencies. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will help MOT and its line agencies improve their efficiency by (i) removing 
overlapping and outdated public administration, (ii) enhancing the financial resources available 
for road projects, (iii) improving the cost-effectiveness of road projects, and (iv) improving 
governance regarding SOEs. 
  
13.  The TA will develop road maps, guidelines, and assessments for three components of 
the road transport subsector: 
(i)  Regarding institutional and financial arrangements, the TA will develop 
(a)  a road map for the long- and medium-term institutional enhancement of 
the operation of MOT and its line agencies (especially the DRVN and 
VEMA)  and  real-time  advisory  support  to  MOT  officials  through  an 
individual consultant stationed in MOT; 
                                                 
11 Technical Cooperation on Project for Capacity Enhancement in Road Maintenance.

4   
(b)  an  assessment  of  the  applicability  of  PPP  arrangements  to  the  My 
Thuan–Can Tho expressway project; 
(c)  an  assessment  of  financial  arrangements,  such  as  combinations  and 
conditions  of  PPP,  official  development  assistance,  and  government 
subsidies, for the each section of the north–south expressway (eastern 
side); and 
(d)  a road map for enhancing VEC’s financial management capacity. 
(ii)  Regarding operation and maintenance, the TA will develop modified guidelines 
with  enhanced  design  flexibility  to  reduce  life-cycle  costs  and  improve  the 
sustainability of expressways, national roads, and local roads. 
(iii)  Regarding governance, the TA will develop 
(a)  guidelines for ADB's procurement involving SOEs under MOT, including 
an assessment for equitized and privatized SOEs and 
(b)  a road map for the participation of selected SOEs under MOT in ADB-
financed projects. 
 
14.  The outputs of the TA will be incorporated into the policy components of planned loan 
projects. MOT and its line agencies should have strong ownership of inputs to the TA and utilize 
the TA outputs. ADB staff and the TA consultant will work closely with senior staff of MOT and 
its line agencies. During the institutional modernization and development phase, which will have 
a 5-year horizon, ADB will work closely with MOT, its line agencies, and other development 
partners and address institutional capacity issues under future loan and TA projects to ensure 
full ownership. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000 equivalent, of which $1,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The 
government will finance the remaining cost of $150,000 through in-kind contributions, which will 
cover  office  and  support  facilities,  counterpart  staff,  administrative  support,  and  local 
transportation for counterpart staff. The cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MOT will be the executing agency. MOT's line agencies—VEC, the DRVN, VEMA, and 
the My Thuan project management unit—will be the implementing agencies, which will request 
MOT  to  provide  capacity-building  support  from  the  TA.  The  executing  and  implementing 
agencies will provide in-kind support for the TA.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over the 11 months from October 2010 to August 2011. 
ADB will recruit a consulting firm and an individual consultant. The consulting firm will be 
selected by quality- and cost-based selection using a quality–cost ratio of 90:10 and simplified 
technical proposals. The firm's consultant team will comprise four international experts—a road 
transport specialist and team leader (9 person-months), public enterprise reform specialist (3 
person-months), public financial management specialist (4 person-months), and procurement 
specialist  (2 person-months)—and  six  national  experts  (21  person-months).  The  individual 
consultant, a road transport specialist (10 person-months), will be stationed in the MOT office 
and provide hands-on advisory support to MOT senior staff on improving the efficiency of the 
DRVN and VEMA and act as a conduit between MOT and the firm's consulting team. The 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). TA-financed equipment will be transferred to

5
the executing agency at the conclusion of the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be done in 
accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  Tripartite  meetings  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies,  ADB,  and  the 
consultant team will be held regularly when ADB missions are fielded to discuss outstanding 
issues  and  actions  to  be  taken  to  address  them.  Quadripartite  meetings  including  other 
development partners will be held in the inception and the final phase, and at other occasions if 
necessary,  to  discuss  major  findings  and  outputs.  Working  groups,  including  experts  and 
representatives of MOT, its line agencies, provincial people's committees, and development 
partners, will be formulated to discuss such matters as flexible design standards and PPP.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction  for  Strengthening  Institutional  and  Financial  Arrangements,  Operation  and 
Maintenance, and Governance in Road Transport, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
  
A.   Consulting Firm 
 
1.  Consultants will support the three components of the technical assistance (TA), under the 
supervision of a team leader, to ensure that the TA achieves its outcomes and outputs within the 
specified time frame. The consultants will work closely with the staff of the Ministry of Transport 
(MOT) and its line agencies to enhance the government’s ownership of the TA. Close coordination 
with development partners like the Japan International Cooperation Agency and the World Bank 
will enhance the effectiveness of the outputs. 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented intermittently by a team of four international consultants for 
18 person-months  and  by  national  consultants  for  21  person-months  for  part  A,  and  by  an 
international individual consultant who will be stationed in MOT for 10 person-months for part B. 
The  team  of  consultants  will  work  closely  with  the  individual  consultant.  The  international 
consultants in the team will be a road transport specialist and team leader (9 person-months), 
public enterprise reform specialist (3 person-months), public financial management specialist (4 
person-months), and procurement specialist (2 person-months). 
 
3.  The  consultants  will  carry  out  a  diagnosis  of  MOT  and  its  line  agencies  in  terms  of 
(i) institutional and financial arrangements, (ii) operation and maintenance, and (iii) governance, 
with reference to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) sector assistance program evaluation report 
in the transport sector1 and other relevant material. Findings will be presented as problem and 
objective trees. The consultants will work with three selected provincial departments of transport 
from the northern, central, and southern regions to discuss and identify key provincial issues.2 In 
the event issues other than those included in these terms of reference (TOR) are found to be 
important, the consultants will propose changes to the TOR. To encourage ownership and promote 
intended outcomes, MOT input on such changes will be solicited and taken into account.  
 
4.  Road transport specialist and team leader (international, 9 person-months, supported by 
national consultants, 9 person-months). The team leader will have a strong background in the road 
transport subsector, especially in government administration, design, project finance, and operation 
and maintenance. The team leader will have at least 10 years of experience in providing similar 
consulting services across a range of technical, political and geographic settings, preferably with 
experience in Viet Nam or other developing countries in Southeast Asia, and an educational 
background in transport, civil engineering, or a related field, preferably with a postgraduate degree. 
 
5.  Tasks will include but not be limited to 
(i)  providing intellectual leadership and substantial guidance on road transport issues to 
the consultant team; 
(ii)  ensuring that MOT takes strong ownership in the TA assignment through continuous 
interaction with decision makers and TA counterpart staff and encouraging MOT to 
participate in defining individual tasks to be carried out by the consultant team; 
(iii)  developing  a  detailed  work  plan  and  progress  reports  for  the  TA  in  close 
consultation with the ADB team and the executing agency’s focal point; 
(iv)  leading the implementation of the operation and maintenance component; and 
(v)  supporting the implementation of all the other components.

7.  Tasks will include but not be limited to 
(i)  working closely with the team leader to incorporate the sector background and 
context to the output; 
(ii)  leading  the  development  of  proposals  for  long-  and  medium-term  institutional 
enhancement; and 
(iii)  supporting the empowerment of financial management in the Vietnam Expressway 
Corporation and the implementation of the governance component.  
 
8.  Public and project financial management specialist (international, 4 person-months, 
supported by national consultants, 6 person-months). The specialist will have at least 5 years of 
experience in project and corporate financing, capacity building and training, and public budget 
allocation across a range of social and political settings, preferably with experience in Viet Nam or 
other developing countries in Southeast Asia. 
 
9.  Tasks will include but not be limited to 
(i)  working closely with the team leader to incorporate the sector background and 
context to the output; 
(ii)  leading the assessment of public–private partnership (PPP) arrangements for the 
My Thuan–Can Tho expressway project and financial arrangements of the north–
south expressway (eastern side) and the empowerment of financial management in 
the Vietnam Expressway Corporation; and 
(iii)  supporting the implementation of the operation and management component.  
 
10.  Procurement  specialist  (international,  2  person-months,  supported  by  national 
consultants, 2 person-months). The specialist will have at least 5 years of experience in developing 
procurement guidelines and procedures across a range of social and political settings, preferably 
with experience in Viet Nam or other developing countries in Southeast Asia. 
 
11.  Tasks will include but not be limited to 
(i)  working closely with the team leader to incorporate the sector background and 
context to the output and 
(ii)  leading the implementation of the governance component. 
 
12.  Meetings and training. The following meetings will be held: (i) a quadripartite meeting in 
the inception phase to discuss major issues at the initial inspection and screening stage, (ii) a 
tripartite meeting in the interim phase to discuss major outputs in the interim report, and (iii) a 
quadripartite meeting including development partners in the final phase to discuss major outputs in 
the draft final report. Working groups, including experts and representatives of MOT, its line 
agencies, provincial people's committees, and development partners, will be formulated to discuss 
such matters as flexible design standards, PPP, and governance. The minutes, including such 
items as the conclusions, major issues discussed, necessary actions, and lists of participants, will 
be prepared within a week following each meeting. Regular meetings will be held between the 
consultant team and the individual consultant stationed in MOT. Training on ADB's procurement

Appendix 3  11 
guidelines involving state-owned enterprises will be held for relevant staff in MOT and its line 
agencies  
 
13.  Reporting requirements. The following reports will be submitted: (i) an inception phase 
report within 4 weeks of the start of activities, (ii) an interim report at the end of 5 months, (iii) a 
draft final report by the end of 9 months, and (vi) a final report and notes on the quadripartite 
meeting within 4 weeks after the receipt of comments on the draft final report. All reports will be 
prepared and submitted in Vietnamese and English. 
 
B.   Individual Consultant 
 
14.  The TA will provide advisory support to MOT on improving the efficiency of the Directorate 
for Roads of Vietnam and Vietnam Expressway Management Administration. The consultant will 
work closely with the staff of MOT and its line agencies to enhance the government’s ownership of 
the TA. 
 
15.  The  consulting  services  for  the  TA  will  be  carried  out  by  an  international  individual 
consultant stationed in MOT for 10 person-months for part B and a team of international and 
national  consultants  for  part  A.  The  consultant  for  part  B  will  act  as  a  conduit  between  the 
consultant team and MOT and its agencies. The consultant will work closely with MOT and the 
consultant team.  
 
16.  The consultant will provide hands-on advisory support to MOT senior staff on improving the 
efficiency of the Directorate for Roads of Vietnam and the Vietnam Expressway Management 
Administration. In the event that issues other than those included in the TOR are found to be 
important, the consultant will propose changes to the TOR. To encourage ownership and promote 
intended outcomes, MOT input on such changes will be solicited and taken into account.  
 
17.  Road transport specialist (international, 10 person-months). The specialist will have a 
strong background in the road transport subsector, especially in public sector administration. The 
specialist will have at least 15 years of experience in providing similar consulting services or public 
sector  work  across  a  range  of  technical,  political,  and  geographic  settings,  preferably  with 
experience in Viet Nam or other developing countries in Southeast Asia; at least 5 years of 
experience related to the public sector in developed countries; and an educational background in 
transport, civil engineering, or a related field, preferably with a postgraduate degree. 
 
18.  Tasks will include but not be limited to providing real-time advisory support to MOT officials 
and  supporting  the  development  of  proposals  for  long-  and  medium-term  institutional 
enhancement. 
 
19.  Meetings. Regular meetings will be held with the consultant team to enhance coordination.  
 
20.  Reporting requirements. The consultant will submit monthly reports and a final report, all 
in English.
